infodynamics.measures.continuous

Interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov1, ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateKraskov2, ConditionalMutualInfoMultiVariateCommon

    public interface ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariate

    Interface for implementations of the conditional mutual information, which may be applied to either multivariate or merely univariate continuous data. That is, it is applied to double[][] data, where the first index is observation number or time, and the second is variable number.

    Usage of the child classes implementing this interface is intended to follow this paradigm:

    1. Construct the calculator;
    2. Set properties using setProperty(String, String) which may now include the property #PROP_TIME_DIFF to specify a source-destination time difference (default 0);
    3. Initialise the calculator using initialise(int, int, int);
    4. Provide the observations/samples for the calculator to set up the PDFs, using:
      • setObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or setObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], boolean[], boolean[], boolean[]) or setObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], boolean[][], boolean[][], boolean[][]) for calculations based on single time-series, OR
      • The following sequence:
        1. startAddObservations(), then
        2. One or more calls to addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int), then
        3. finaliseAddObservations();
    5. Compute the required quantities, being one or more of:
      • the average MI: computeAverageLocalOfObservations();
      • the local MI values for these samples: computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
      • local MI values for a specific set of samples: computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][])
      • the distribution of MI values under the null hypothesis of no relationship between source and destination values: computeSignificance(int, int) or computeSignificance(int, int[][]).
    6. Return to step 2 or 3 to re-use the calculator on a new data set.

    Author:
    Joseph Lizier (email, www)
    See Also:
    "T. M. Cover and J. A. Thomas, 'Elements of Information Theory' (John Wiley & Sons, New York, 1991)."

      • initialise

        void initialise(int var1Dimensions,
              int var2Dimensions,
              int condDimentions)
                throws java.lang.Exception
        Initialise the calculator for (re-)use, clearing PDFs, with the existing (or default) values of parameters (except the numbers of joint variables) as specified below
        Parameters:
        var1Dimensions - the number of joint variables in variable 1
        var2Dimensions - the number of joint variables in variable 2
        condDimensions - the number of joint variables in the conditional
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setProperty

        void setProperty(java.lang.String propertyName,
               java.lang.String propertyValue)
                 throws java.lang.Exception
        Set properties for the calculator. New property values are not guaranteed to take effect until the next call to an initialise method.

        No general properties are defined at the interface level here, i.e. there are only properties defined by child interfaces and classes.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        propertyValue - value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

        java.lang.String getProperty(java.lang.String propertyName)
                             throws java.lang.Exception

        Valid property names, and what their values should represent, are the same as those for setProperty(String, String)

        Unknown property values are responded to with a null return value.

        Parameters:
        propertyName - name of the property
        Returns:
        current value of the property
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - for invalid property values

      • setObservations

        void setObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF. Cannot be called in conjunction with startAddObservations() / addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int) / finaliseAddObservations().

        The supplied series may be (multivariate) time-series or simply a set of separate observations without a time interpretation.

        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setObservations

        void setObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond,
                   boolean[] var1Valid,
                   boolean[] var2Valid,
                   boolean[] condValid)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF, where all the various observations are valid. Cannot be called in conjunction with startAddObservations() / addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int) / finaliseAddObservations().

        The supplied series may be (multivariate) time-series or simply a set of separate observations without a time interpretation.

        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        var1Valid - series (with indices the same as var1) indicating whether var1 at that point is valid.
        var2Valid - series (with indices the same as var2) indicating whether var2 at that point is valid.
        condValid - series (with indices the same as cond) indicating whether cond at that point is valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setObservations

        void setObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond,
                   boolean[][] var1Valid,
                   boolean[][] var2Valid,
                   boolean[][] condValid)
                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Sets a single series from which to compute the PDF, where the observations are valid for all individual variables. Cannot be called in conjunction with startAddObservations() / addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) or addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int) / finaliseAddObservations().

        The supplied series may be (multivariate) time-series or simply a set of separate observations without a time interpretation.

        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        var1Valid - series (with indices the same as var1) indicating whether each variable of var1 at that point is valid.
        var2Valid - series (with indices the same as var2) indicating whether each variable of var2 at that point is valid.
        condValid - series (with indices the same as cond) indicating whether each variable of cond at that point is valid.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • startAddObservations

        void startAddObservations()
        Signal that we will add in the samples for computing the PDF from several disjoint time-series or trials via calls to "addObservations" rather than "setObservations" type methods (defined by the child interfaces and classes).

      • addObservations

        void addObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond)
                     throws java.lang.Exception

        Adds a new set of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after startAddObservations(); call finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Note that the arrays must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • addObservations

        void addObservations(double[][] var1,
                   double[][] var2,
                   double[][] cond,
                   int startTime,
                   int numTimeSteps)
                     throws java.lang.Exception

        Adds a new sub-series of observations to update the PDFs with - is intended to be called multiple times. Must be called after startAddObservations(); call finaliseAddObservations() once all observations have been supplied.

        Note that the arrays must not be over-written by the user until after finaliseAddObservations() has been called (they are not copied by this method necessarily, but the method may simply hold a pointer to them).

        Parameters:
        var1 - multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        var2 - multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        cond - multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number) Length must match var1, and their indices must correspond.
        startTime - first time index to take observations on
        numTimeSteps - number of time steps to use (including startTime)
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

                             throws java.lang.Exception
        Signal that the observations are now all added, PDFs can now be constructed.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations()
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the average conditional MI from the previously-supplied samples.
        Returns:
        the estimate of the conditional MI in either bits or nats depending on the estimator
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalOfPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalOfPreviousObservations()
                                            throws java.lang.Exception

        Computes the local values of the conditional mutual information, for each valid observation in the previously supplied observations (with PDFs computed using all of the previously supplied observation sets).

        If the samples were supplied via a single call such as setObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]), then the return value is a single time-series of local channel measure values corresponding to these samples.

        Otherwise where disjoint time-series observations were supplied using several calls such as addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) then the local values for each disjoint observation set will be appended here to create a single "time-series" return array.

        Returns:
        the "time-series" of local conditional MI values in either bits or nats depending on the estimator.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int variableToReorder,
                                                   int numPermutationsToCheck)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the conditional MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the variable identified by variableToReorder had no relation to the other variable, given the conditional.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for conditional MI. Basically, we shuffle the observations of variableToReorder against the other variable and the conditional. This keeps the marginal and joint PDFs of the unshuffled variable and conditional the same but destroys any correlation between the named variable and the others.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int, int[][])) creates random shufflings of the next values for the surrogate AIS calculations.

        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        numPermutationsToCheck - number of surrogate samples to bootstrap to generate the distribution.
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeSignificance

        EmpiricalMeasurementDistribution computeSignificance(int variableToReorder,
                                                   int[][] newOrderings)
                                                     throws java.lang.Exception
        Generate a bootstrapped distribution of what the conditional MI would look like, under a null hypothesis that the variable identified by variableToReorder had no relation to the other variable, given the conditional.

        See Section II.E "Statistical significance testing" of the JIDT paper below for a description of how this is done for conditional MI. Basically, we shuffle the observations of variableToReorder against the other variable and the conditional. This keeps the marginal and joint PDFs of the unshuffled variable and conditional the same but destroys any correlation between the named variable and the others.

        Note that if several disjoint time-series have been added as observations using addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) etc., then these separate "trials" will be mixed up in the generation of surrogates here.

        This method (in contrast to computeSignificance(int, int)) allows the user to specify how to construct the surrogates, such that repeatable results may be obtained.

        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        newOrderings - a specification of how to shuffle the values of the variable specified by variableToReorder to create the surrogates to generate the distribution with. The first index is the permutation number (i.e. newOrderings.length is the number of surrogate samples we use to bootstrap to generate the distribution here.) Each array newOrderings[i] should be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        the distribution of channel measure scores under this null hypothesis.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - where the length of each permutation in newOrderings is not equal to the number N samples that were previously supplied.
        See Also:
        "J.T. Lizier, 'JIDT: An information-theoretic toolkit for studying the dynamics of complex systems', 2014."

      • computeAverageLocalOfObservations

        double computeAverageLocalOfObservations(int variableToReorder,
                                       int[] newOrdering)
                                         throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the conditional mutual information if the given variable were ordered as per the ordering specified in newOrdering
        Parameters:
        variableToReorder - which variable to shuffle: 1 for variable 1, 2 for variable 2.
        newOrdering - permutation of the indices for the given variable; must be an array of length N (where would be the value returned by getNumObservations()), containing a permutation of the values in 0..(N-1).
        Returns:
        conditional MI under this reordering
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations

        double[] computeLocalUsingPreviousObservations(double[][] states1,
                                             double[][] states2,
                                             double[][] condStates)
                                               throws java.lang.Exception
        Compute the local conditional MI values for each of the supplied samples in states1, states2 and condStates.

        PDFs are computed using all of the previously supplied observations, but not those in states1, states2 and condStates (unless they were some of the previously supplied samples).

        Parameters:
        states1 - series of multivariate observations for variable 1 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number)
        states2 - series of multivariate observations for variable 2 (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match states1, and their indices must correspond.
        condStates - series of multivariate observations for the conditional (first index is time or observation index, second is variable number). Length must match states1, and their indices must correspond.
        Returns:
        the series of local conditional MI values.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception

      • setDebug

        void setDebug(boolean debug)
        Set or clear debug mode for extra debug printing to stdout
        Parameters:
        debug - new setting for debug mode (on/off)

      • getLastAverage

        double getLastAverage()
        Return the conditional MI last calculated in a call to computeAverageLocalOfObservations() or computeLocalOfPreviousObservations() after the previous initialise(int, int, int) call.
        Returns:
        the last computed conditional MI value

      • getNumObservations

        int getNumObservations()
                       throws java.lang.Exception
        Get the number of samples to be used for the PDFs here which have been supplied by calls to setObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]), addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) etc.
        Returns:
        the number of samples to be used for the PDFs
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the implementing class computes MI without explicit observations (e.g. see ConditionalMutualInfoCalculatorMultiVariateGaussian)

      • getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet

        boolean getAddedMoreThanOneObservationSet()
        Get whether the user has added more than one observation set via the addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][]) and addObservations(double[][], double[][], double[][], int, int) methods.
        Returns:
        whether the user has added more than one observation set.
